awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: How do predators spread disease? Tests of five ecological and eco-evolutionary mechanisms with disease in the plankton
awd_abstract_narration:
A practical goal of disease ecologists is to find ways to stop or slow the spread of infection from host to host. A popular idea is that predators control disease outbreaks by killing infected prey which are weaker and thereby easier to capture. However, this proposal warns that predators may sometimes spread disease in host populations. The researchers will use organisms living in lakes to test five ways in which predators could spread disease. These ideas are that predators: (1) while eating prey, physically spread parasites into prey habitat; (2) can increase food supply for prey, and more food can cause higher parasite production within infected hosts; (3) can shift the composition of prey populations towards certain ages and sizes that get infected more easily; (4) can kill other species that control disease; and (5) can cause genetic changes to prey populations, making them more susceptible to disease organisms. The project will focus on water fleas (the hosts), a deadly fungal parasite, and an insect predator to test these possibilities. The research uses these organisms as a model system: outbreaks of this fungus can be sampled in lakes, created in experiments within lakes and in the lab, and can be understood using mathematical models. These new ideas, once tested thoroughly in the lab and verified in nature, will help managers make prudent decisions on how to control disease outbreaks in wild and domestic animal populations. The project will train many students, and focus on engaging those in underrepresented groups.
 
This project integrates three approaches. First, it will invest in a survey of fungal epidemics in water flea hosts in 40 lakes. The data from this large survey will be used to generate complex statistical models that test the first four mechanisms (ideas) given above. Second, it uses controlled experiments. One experiment will test mechanisms (2)-(4) with factorial manipulation of predatory insects and "competitor-diluters" (other water flea species which eat parasite propagules). A second experiment will investigate details of mechanisms (1)-(3). A third experiment investigates a tradeoff among clonal genotypes of the host; genotypes which better escape predation are more vulnerable to parasites. The hypothesis is that predators will shift host populations, via rapid evolution, towards bigger epidemics via this tradeoff. Third, this project develops a new suite of parameterized, mathematical (dynamical) models, designed to evaluate each of the mechanisms separately and together.

por.por_cntn:
Will a changing globe see larger epidemics of infectious disease in wildlife? Answers may hinge upon other species that shape interactions between hosts and virulent parasites. We focused on predators and resources of hosts as drivers of epidemics. Specifically, we evaluated mechanisms by which predators could either spread disease (‘predator spreaders’) or inhibit it. Additionally, we evaluated how the response of food resources could alter disease epidemics and density of hosts. While developing these mechanisms, we also pushed into analyses of loops.

 

Mechanisms of predator spreaders:

(1) ‘Cascade fueling’: We built mathematical models linking predators to disease spread via parasite production. Specifically, because they enhance mortality of their prey (hosts), predators can increase density of food resources of hosts (via a ‘trophic cascade’). Higher resource density, in turn, can increase production of parasites by infected hosts. If propagules limited new infections, predators could spread disease through this ‘cascade fueling’ mechanism. We found evidence for it in surveys of epidemics of a virulent fungus infecting zooplankton (waterflea) populations in lakes. Additionally, we found support in a mesocosm experiment. However, in another series of experiments, we found less.

 

(2) ‘Killing the young’: Predators could also spread disease that mostly targets adults by selectively preying on juvenile life stages of their prey, i.e., by ‘killing the young’. We first developed a suite of models that delineate how this deceptively complex mechanism works. We found evidence for it in our field surveys: lakes with larger populations of a midges shifted populations of their waterflea prey towards adults, and that pattern correlated with larger epidemics. One experiment straightforwardly supported it, while a large one showed when it may not (but predictably so).

 

(3) ‘Killing the diluter’: Predators may spread disease by preferentially killing ‘diluters’. These ‘diluters’ reduce the size of epidemics by competing with hosts for food resources and by eating infectious propagules without becoming infected themselves (thereby reducing disease transmission). We developed mathematical models, found evidence for it in field surveys, and demonstrated it in a mesocosm experiment.

 

(4) Rapid evolution of increased susceptibility: Predators could trigger rapid evolution of hosts towards higher susceptibility to parasites that kill them. The underlying mechanism involves increases in host resources (from predation) and key tradeoffs among hosts (in birth rate vs. resistance to infection). We tested this prediction, but predators in that experiment controlled epidemics while hosts evolved little.

 

Host-resource interactions

These projects involved interactions between hosts, parasites, and resources. Hence, we focused on these interactions as well.

 

(5) Parasite-mediated ‘hydras’ vs. ‘cascades’: Epidemics of parasites can reduce host density and increase density of their resources. (Predators can create similar ‘trophic cascades’). In an experiment, we compared and contrasted the magnitude of cascades caused by parasites vs. by predators. We found those caused by epidemics can become massive, especially when propagules and infection cause decrease in size of hosts, i.e., when they cause ‘trait-mediated indirect effects’. We confirmed those ideas with a suite of experiments. However, deadly parasites can increase density of hosts through a ‘hydra effect’. We used a series of models to delineate when and why that happens, and we show both field and experimental evidence for it.

 

(6) ‘Resistance is futile’: By causing trophic cascades, parasites could catalyze rapid evolution of increased susceptibility (lower resistance to parasites). We developed several models for this mechanism and show evidence for it in several experiments (with suggestive field patterns as well). This ‘resistance is futile’ mechanism can elevate the size of epidemics and depress further the density of hosts.

 

 

Feedback loops and the dynamics of species interactions

(7) These projects forced deeper thinking about fundamental forces underlying dynamics of species interactions. These include dynamics that enable species to enter into systems, that create alternative stable states, and that unleash fluctuations. We invested in a ‘deep dive’ into these forces with loop analysis. It allows us to trace one, two, three, etc., species interactions that generate positive or negative feedback. We used these loop analyses to answer: (A) why do parasites cause systems to fluctuate, (B) how are within-host and food web interactions similar and different, and (C) how can we connect our classic models for species interactions to these feedback loops? Through these efforts, we developed ways of thinking that extend beyond confines of predators, hosts, and resources.

 

 

Broader impacts

The grant supported several forms of outreach, although the pandemic inhibited some efforts. First, pre-pandemic we hosted various groups of high school students from URM backgrounds to conduct experiments with us. We also worked on linking mathematical models with field observations with other groups. Furthermore, we contributed to large public-facing events (“Science Fest”), introducing hundreds of children to lake sampling and parasites. We trained several groups of high school teachers to use plankton for experiments in their classrooms. Finally, the project supported five dissertations at Indiana.
